Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will demonstrate a new class of continuum robots capable of multi-scale manipulation, that is, the ability to achieve large motion with millimetric precision and to achieve small motion with micrometer-scale precision. Existing robots are typically designed to function properly only at a single operational length scale. The envisioned class of robots will provide micro-precision while traversing macroscale sinuous pathways to access the operational site, thus enabling new technologies for micro-surgery, such as image-based biopsy (high resolution tissue inspection), and micro-surgery in deep surgical fields. Potential benefits include precise tissue reconstruction and complete surgical eradication of tumors. Such robots will also enable new abilities for micro-manufacturing, leading to greatly improved quality-control inspection methods for micro-fluidic and microelectromechanical devices mass-manufactured on large substrates.

The goal of this research is to provide modeling and control frameworks for new types of parallel continuum robots for multi-scale manipulation, based on the concept of equilibrium modulation. These robots will use direct actuation of their links to achieve large workspace with macro (millimetric scale) precision and indirect-actuation to perturb the equilibrium pose of the continuum robot to achieve minute (micrometer scale) motions. This concept differs from existing approaches for multi-scale manipulation by offering one robotic architecture capable of both micro and macro manipulation. The modeling approach will provide a formulation supporting calibration, system identification and control. This project will use a direct variational approach for modeling the statics and kinematics of these robots, and a framework for micro-motion modeling and parameter identification using support vector regressors to overcome friction and parameter uncertainties. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) as a means for micro-inspection, and control feedback approaches using mixed joint-space and OCT feedback will be used to enable semi-automated scans of the target inspection site.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Existing robots are typically designed to function properly only at a single functional length scale and, whenever multi-scale motion is needed, the problem is solved by serially stacking a micro-scale robot (a robot that has a very small workspace, but can move at or less than micron-scale precision) at the distal end of a macro-scale robot (a robot that provides a large workspace and moves with mm scale precision). Such arrangement is not always feasible in confined spaces or in applications where miniaturization is critical.

To address this need, the main goal of this project was to investigate, develop, and demonstrate the control of a new class of parallel continuum robots capable of multi-scale manipulation, that is, the ability to achieve large motion with millimetric precision and to achieve small motion with micrometer-scale precision. The award supported the verification, modeling and control of a new concept of continuum robots with equilibrium modulation (CREM). Referring to Figure 1, these robots use direct actuation of their tubular backbones to achieve large workspace with macro (millimetric scale) precision and indirect-actuation by sliding wires inside the tubular backbones to perturb the equilibrium pose of the continuum robot in order to achieve minute (micron-scale) motions. This concept differs from existing approaches for multi-scale manipulation, by offering one robotic architecture capable of both micro and macro manipulation.

As a benchmark for testing the feasibility and promise of our proposed control and modeling approach for CREM, we set forth the goal of establishing a control framework that resolved how to split the motion between macro and micro-scale (a process called redundancy resolution) and a control feedback approach that uses image-guidance from micro-scale measurements (e.g. by using optical coherence tomography (OCT) imaging feedback) and joint-level measurements. The ultimate experimental verification goal of this award was to demonstrate the promise of CREM for enabling the attainment of three-dimensional optical coherence tomography image volumes by using micro-scale motion to move an OCT probe integrated with the robot.

We first developed algorithms for micron-scale vision tracking of robots since commercial trackers cannot achieve sub-micron motion tracking. We then created a simplified mechanics-based model for modeling the micro-motion kinematics of these robots. The work presented the use of moment coupling effects and an experimental calibration approach that was able to predict the motion of such robots with better than 5 microns modeling error. If high resolution micron-scale image feedback is available, then these robots could be controlled with higher precision. Figure 2 shows some experimental results obtained by coupling an OCT probe with a CREM robot for scanning the shape of a screw thread. Figure 3 shows the OCT scan of a pig optic nerve using CREM. Finally, Figure 4 shows a demonstration of a successful multi-scale motion using closed loop OCT-guided micro-motion for guiding a mock needle into a miniature mock vessel in agar medium.

The award supported the training of 3 Ph.D. students, 2 undergraduate students, and 1 high-school student. These students have enjoyed an interdisciplinary project involving computer-science, mechanical engineering and system integration. In addition, 3 peer-reviewed papers (2 conference and 1 journal paper) have been published and 2 more are planned at the time of this report. One invention disclosure has been also filed as a patent application at the U.S. patent office.

We envision that the multi-scale motion capabilities of continuum robots will provide micro-precision while traversing macroscale sinuous pathways to access the operational site. Such multi-scale capability enables new technologies for micro-surgery, such as image-based biopsy (high resolution tissue inspection), and micro-surgery in deep surgical fields. Potential societal benefits include precise tissue reconstruction and complete surgical eradication of tumors. Such robots will also enable new abilities for micro-manufacturing, leading to greatly improved in-situ quality-control inspection methods.

Publications:

 1) Giuseppe Del Giudice, Jin-Hui Shen, Karen Joos, Nabil Simaan (2019). Feasibility of Volumetric OCT Imaging using Continuum Robots with Equilibrium Modulation.  Hamlyn Symposium on Medical Robotics, London U.K., 2019.

2) Giuseppe Del Giudice, Long Wang, Jin Hui Shen, Karen Joos, Nabil Simaan (2017). Continuum Robots for Multi-Scale Motion: Micro-Scale Motion through Equilibrium Modulation.  IEEE/RSJ International Conference on Intelligent Robots and Systems. DOI: 10.1109/IROS.2017.8206074

3) Long Wang, Giuseppe Del Giudice, Nabil Simaan (2019). Simplified Kinematics of Continuum Robot Equilibrium Modulation via Moment Coupling Effects and Model Calibration.  ASME Transactions on Mechanisms and Robotics. Vol. 11, no. 5, pp. 051013.
